title: Samuel Newitt Wood
text:
Samuel Newitt Wood (December 30, 1825 – June 23, 1891) was an American attorney, politician, and <a href="Slave%20states%20and%20free%20states">Free State</a> advocate in Kansas.
Wood represented <a href="Chase%20County%2C%20Kansas">Chase</a>, <a href="Morris%20County%2C%20Kansas">Morris</a>, and Madison counties in the Kansas Territorial Legislature in 1860 and 1861, was a member of the first <a href="Kansas%20State%20Senate">Kansas State Senate</a> in 1861 and again in 1867, a member of the <a href="Kansas%20House%20of%20Representatives">Kansas House of Representatives</a> in 1864, 1866, 1876, and 1877, and speaker during the last session.
Early life & family.
Samuel Newitt Wood was born at <a href="Mount%20Gilead%2C%20Ohio">Mount Gilead, Ohio</a>, December 30, 1825, fifth child to David and Esther Ward (Mosher) Wood. His paternal grandfather was a leader in the meetings of the Orthodox Quakers until his death. His maternal grandfather became a leader in the more progressive wing of the <a href="Society%20of%20Friends">Society of Friends</a> known as the <a href="Hicksites">Hicksites</a>. Having been raised a <a href="Quaker">Quaker</a>, Wood's hatred for <a href="slavery">slavery</a> grew very strong. His family home was the site of a station on the <a href="Underground%20Railroad">Underground Railroad</a>. In 1849, during one of his many attempts to carry runaway slaves to freedom, he met his future wife, Margaret Lyon, daughter of William and Elizabeth Lyon. They were married on October 3, 1850. Their children were: David, born August 25, 1851; William Lyon, born March 10, 1853; Florence, born January 20, 1857; Dearie, born July 7, 1865.
Bleeding Kansas.
After the <a href="Kansas-Nebraska%20Act">Kansas-Nebraska Act</a> was passed on May 30, 1854, Samuel moved his family to Lawrence, Kansas. After the murder of Charles Dow, on November 21, 1855, Samuel took part in the Rescue of Jacob Branson which occurred on November 26, 1855.
Newspaper publisher.
In the 1850s Wood was part owner of the "Kansas Tribune" of <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Kansas">Lawrence</a>. In 1859 he established the first newspapers at <a href="Cottonwood%20Falls%2C%20Kansas">Cottonwood Falls</a>, "The Kansas Press", and at <a href="Council%20Grove%2C%20Kansas">Council Grove</a>, "The Council Grove Press." In 1878 to 1879 he was connected with "The Kansas Greenbacker" of <a href="Emporia%2C%20Kansas">Emporia</a>. He was also associated with "The Topeka State Journal", "The Woodsdale Democrat", and "The Woodsdale Sentinel" of <a href="Stevens%20County%2C%20Kansas">Stevens County, Kansas</a>. In 1881 he was editor-in-chief of the "Kansas State Journal."
Military career.
Wood's service in the Civil War began as <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a> of Company I (nicknamed the "Kansas Rangers"), <a href="2nd%20Regiment%20Kansas%20Volunteer%20Infantry">2nd Kansas Infantry</a>, which fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Wilson%27s%20Creek">Battle of Wilson's Creek</a>. Afterward he was assigned to the <a href="6th%20Missouri%20Cavalry%20Regiment%20%28Union%29">6th Missouri Cavalry Regiment (Union)</a>, "<a href="John%20C.%20Fr%C3%A9mont">Fremont's Battalion</a>", which he had recruited, serving as <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> and subsequently <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a>. He fought at the battle near Salem, and formed a part of the command of <a href="Major%20General%20%28United%20States%29">Maj. Gen.</a> <a href="Samuel%20Ryan%20Curtis">Samuel Curtis</a> in his campaign through <a href="Arkansas">Arkansas</a>. In 1864, Wood was appointed <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of the Kansas State Militia.
Suffrage Movements.
On November 18, 1852, Samuel's mother, Esther Ward (Mosher) Wood served as President of an Ohio Women's Rights Convention held at the Presbyterian church in Mount Gilead. The Vice-Presidents were; Charlotte Cook, and Mrs. A. E. Gurley. Phoebe Spencer was secretary and Mrs. Frances Dana Gage gave an address.
On January 21, 1860, S. N. Wood introduced House Bill No.6, entitled "An act to prohibit slavery or involuntary servitude in Kansas", and it was referred to the Committee on
Judiciary, of which he was chairman. On February 2 it passed the House by a vote of 30 to 6. On February 11 the Council passed it by a vote of 9 to 4. This bill called out a veto message from Governor Medary of fifteen pages in length; and on February 21 it was passed over his veto by a vote of 30 to 7 in the House, and 9 to 4 in the Council.
In 1866, Samuel was one of the leaders who proposed an amendment to the Kansas State Constitution which would strike out the words "male" and "white". 
On April 2, 1867, Samuel organized the Impartial Suffrage movement in Topeka, Kansas. Through this group he brought in the speakers; <a href="Henry%20B.%20Blackwell">Henry B. Blackwell</a>, of New Jersey, Mrs. <a href="Lucy%20Stone">Lucy Stone</a>, <a href="Elizabeth%20Cady%20Stanton">Elizabeth Cady Stanton</a>, <a href="Olympia%20Brown">Olympia Brown</a>, <a href="Bessie%20Bisbee">Bessie Bisbee</a> and <a href="Susan%20B.%20Anthony">Susan B. Anthony</a>.
Political career.
Involved in politics from an early age, Wood was chairman of the <a href="Liberty%20Party%20%281840s%29">Liberty Party</a> Central Committee of his county in 1844. He was admitted to the bar in Morrow County, Ohio in 1854 and when the Kansas-Nebraska act was passed, Wood and his family moved to near Lawrence at Wakarusa, Kansas where he joined the Free State Party. He also participated in Jacob Branson's rescue which brought about the short-lived <a href="Wakarusa%20War">Wakarusa War</a> in 1855.
Wood was a delegate to and spoke at the <a href="History%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Republican%20Party">Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania Convention</a> which organized the <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican Party</a> in 1856. He was a delegate to the <a href="Leavenworth%20Constitution">Leavenworth Constitution</a> Convention in 1858. 
On July 27, 1861, he was appointed and commissioned by President <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> as <a href="Collector%20of%20Customs">Collector of Customs</a> at <a href="El%20Paso%E2%80%93Ju%C3%A1rez">Paso del Norte</a>, <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>. He resigned this position at the start of the Civil War.
In 1867, Wood was appointed Judge of the 9th Judicial District.
Stevens County seat war.
As the founder of <a href="Woodsdale%2C%20Kansas">Woodsdale, Kansas</a>, Wood strongly advocated that his town would become the county seat of <a href="Stevens%20County%2C%20Kansas">Stevens County</a>, which locked him in a contentious battle with the rival town of <a href="Hugoton%2C%20Kansas">Hugoton</a>. One of the events of this confrontation was the <a href="Hay%20Meadow%20Massacre">Hay Meadow Massacre</a>, in which Hugoton supporters disarmed and murdered four Woodsdale supporters. Wood attempted to prosecute the men, but it was ruled that no court had jurisdiction in "No Man's Land" (the <a href="Oklahoma%20Panhandle">Oklahoma Panhandle</a>) where the event took place. Woodsdale is now a <a href="List%20of%20ghost%20towns%20in%20Kansas">ghost town</a>, with nothing remaining of the settlement.
Death.
As a direct result of the vicious county seat fight, Wood was assassinated outside the Hugoton courthouse on June 23, 1891, by James Brennen. Wood was buried in Prairie Grove Cemetery in Cottonwood Falls. His murderer was never prosecuted for the assassination. His brother, Indian Agent, Rev. <a href="David%20John%20Mosher%20Wood">David John Mosher Wood</a> spoke at his funeral.
Legacy.
<a href="Woods%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Woods County, Oklahoma</a> was named in his honor.
"Song of Samuel Wood" © words & music by Carl Reed 2014, performed by Tallgrass Express.
Sister Jeanne McKenna wrote her 1968 St. Louis University dissertation on Sam Wood, entitled "Samuel N. Wood: Chronic Agitator." Part of it was printed in the Kansas Historical Quarterly 36 (1970) pages 13–21 entitled "With the Help of God and Lucy Stone." Although it contains many false assumptions and inaccuracies.
